descriptions.content:
Interrogative sentences end with final interrogative particles, the precise form of which is determined by the last letter of the preceding auxiliary.

  • ངས་ is used after ང་
  • གས་ is used after ག་
  • པས་ is used in all other cases

For example: ཡིན་པས་, རེད་པས་, ཡོད་པས་, སོང་ངས་, མྱོང་ངས་, བྱུང་ངས་, འདུག་གས་.

Final interrogative particles are not used with these copulas and auxiliaries when a sentence already contains an interrogative pronoun (such as ག་རེ་ “what,” སུ་ “who,” etc.).

However, with the verb ཡིན་, a final interrogative particle པ་ is sometimes used. If there is no interrogative pronoun in the question, the sentence ends with ཡིན་པས་, the interrogative form of the verb ཡིན་; if the question does contain an interrogative pronoun, the sentence ends in ཡིན་པ་ or ཡིན་.

  • ཁྱེད་རང་དགེ་རྒན་ཡིན་པས། “Are you a teacher?”
  • སུ་ཡིན་པ། = སུ་ཡིན། “Who are you?”
